text: “What’s wrong with you today?” I stare into her eyes. “From the moment you walked in, it’s like you’ve frozen yourself over.”
Her gaze lifts, like the edge of a blade flashing out of its sheath for a split second.
“You don’t need to know.”
The sentence is short, but it feels like a door slammed shut. Lucia freezes mid-motion with the ointment in her hand, visibly flustered.
“Master… he’s just worried about you.”
“Worried?” she repeats faintly, as if tasting a word that doesn’t belong.
“Lucia, don’t teach others to interfere.”
Lucia’s eyes redden instantly, but she doesn’t cry. Instead, she carefully pulls the medicine basket closer, as if tightening her grip could steady the situation.
“You could at least—”
“No.”
“Today, I just want to rest.”
She stands. Her cloak sways lightly, as if carrying all her emotions away with it.
“Two rooms.”
“Give her the key.”
“I—I understand…”
She turns and walks upstairs, her footsteps unnervingly light—as if afraid that making any sound might cause her to crack.
The creak of the staircase fades. Only the crackling of the hearth remains.
Lucia bites her lip and forces a small smile, as if apologizing on her master’s behalf.
“...I’m sorry. She doesn’t dislike you. She’s just… holding on with everything she has.”
I let out a breath and shake my head. “It’s fine. You don’t need to apologize for her.”
Lucia finally seems to relax just a little, though her shoulders remain tense, her fingers gripping the edge of the basket until they turn pale.
“If she needs rest, let her rest.” I glance toward the stairs. “And don’t push yourself too hard either.”
She sniffles and nods firmly. “...Okay. I’ll keep an eye on her.”
